awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate the low-frequency variability of the tropical atmosphere and oceans.  Research activities fall into three broad areas. First, predictability of intraseasonal variability accompanying the Asian monsoon.  Earlier work suggests variations in monsoon rainfall which can cause severe flooding and substantial agricultural impacts in South Asia may be predictable, and work under this grant will construct and test forecasting methods for this intraseasonal variability.  Second, the thermodynamic and dynamic processes which determine the size of the western Pacific warm pool, the region of largest sea surface temperature (SST) in the Pacific ocean, which is characterized by large-scale atmospheric convection and precipitation.  The area of the warm pool has increased dramatically over the last 30 years, yet the area of large-scale convection has remained constant.  Work conducted here seeks to determine the factors which control the size of the warm pool and convecting region and determine their year-to-year variability and long-term secular change.  Third, the underlying dynamics of the year-to-year variability of the Asian monsoon.  The work will focus on the possibility that years of extremely deficient and extremely excessive monsoon rainfall in India may be predictable.

The broader impacts of the work go beyond the scientific goals of understanding tropical climate dynamics, since fluctuations in monsoon rainfall have severe effects on the populations of South and Southeast Asia.  The research has a strong emphasis on developing forecast methodologies which could be of considerable practical value.  In addition, research funds will provide training, education, and support for two graduate students and two postdoctoral scholars.

por.por_cntn:
During the last 6 years we have investigated a number of problems related to the weather and climate of the tropics. The overall purpose has been to identify the physical processes that produce the slow variability in the tropics. This understanding is critical as it produces rainfall variability in large sections of the developing world and also influences the weather and climate over the United States and other parts of the subtropics. Such variations result in feast or famine, flood or drought.

Some of our major findings are described below:

(1) Monsoon Weather and Climate:

A major emphasis of our research has been on the monsoons which impact over half of the population on the planet. A perennial problem has been our inability to forecast or foreshadow the whether a monsoon region will have a strong or weak rainfall. Will it be supportive of agriculture or will it hinder food production? This is important as too much rainfall means flooding and too little means famine. We have determined that seasonal forecasting of the South Asian monsoon may have little predictability. It has been noticed that a weak monsoon often coincides with an El Nino and a strong monsoon with a La Nina. But there is evidence that the strong/weak monsoon initiates a La Nina/El Nino. Irrespective, there is little predictive capability.

Given the lack of seasonal predictability we concentrated on attempting to forecast subseasonal variability, in particular on biweekly time scales. We have managed to relate these variations to large scale weather events in the higher summer latitudes that slide into the tropics and impact East Asia before travelling across the Indian Ocean and India. Prediction on this time scale is very useful for agricultural purposes and also for providing severe weather and hazard forecasts. 

 (2) Long-term variability of the global monsoon system:

The consensus among climate modelers is that as the planet warms, monsoon precipitation will reduce and the Hadley and Walker Circulations should weaken also. However, we found that during the recent period 1979-2011, monsoon rainfall (viewed in a global context) has increased together with the tropical circulations (the  Hadley and Walker Cells) have increased in vigor. The intensification is primarily attributed to a mega-El Niño/Southern Oscillation and the Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation, and further influenced by hemispherical asymmetric in global warming. These factors driving the present changes of the NHSM system are instrumental for understanding and predicting future decadal changes and determining the proportions of climate change that are attributable to anthropogenic effects and natural long-term internal variability in the complex climate system. Most likely, these results suggest a combination of anthropogenic forcing and natural variability.

 (3) Dynamics and thermodynamics of the tropical warm pool:

Hoyos and Webster (2012) studied the increasing temperature of the warm pool that has occurred over the last century. They noted that the SST threshold for convective areas moved to higher SSTs whilst the surface area of convection remained the same although at a greater intensity.  There are major implications of this work. It means that the areas where tropical cyclones are formed will be the same. But it also means, if SST continues to increase that tropical cyclones or hurricanes will become more intense.

Modified by: Peter J Webster
